Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China Institute of Process Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China In view of the harsh conditions of cyclic esterification reaction of ethylene glycol (EG) and carbon dioxide (CO2) to synthesize ethylene carbonate (EC), the yield is low and the catalysts are mostly metals, a series of green acid-base bicentric ionic liquids (ABbILs) were developed. Among them, the ABbILs of 1,5,7-Triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec‑5-ene glutarimide ([TBDH][Glu]) had the best catalytic performance. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the yield of EC reached 29.5%, which was higher than most of the conventional metal-based catalysts. Through activity screening results and DFT calculation, it was found that different cations affect the interaction between N on anion and H proton of EG, and the H on the cation can activate the O on EG, which would affect the ability of ABbILs to activate EG. The acid-base bicentered synergistic catalytic mechanism of Bronsted acid and Lewis base was proposed by characterization and DFT calculation. This study opens up new avenues for the efficient conversion of diols and CO2 for the preparation of cyclic carbonates. Graphical abstract A series of green acid-base bicentric ionic liquids (ABbILs) were developed to catalyze the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from ethylene glycol (EG), CO2 and styrene oxide (SO). The addition of SO has a promoting effect on the reaction. On the one hand, SO avoids the hydrolysis of ethylene carbonate (EC) by removing H2O through reacting with H2O, which improves the yield of EC; on the other hand, SO reacts with CO2 to generate styrene carbonate (SC), which further generates EC by transesterification with EG, which promotes the yield of EC. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide Ethylene glycol Cyclic carbonates Acid-base bicentric ionic liquids Cyclic esterification reaction Abbreviations EG Ehylene Glycol EC Ethylene Carbonate SO Styrene Oxide SC Styrene Carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an important C1 resource, and its resource utilization can not only reduce the greenhouse effect, but also transform it into high-value chemicals to bring economic benefits. In this respect, different chemicals are synthesized with CO2 as the original raw material just as the reductive transformation of CO2 into methanol [1–3], formic acid [4–6], CO [7–9], hydrocarbons [10–12], methane [13–15] and so on. As well as for the non-reductive transformation into cyclic carbonate [16–18], dimethyl carbonate [19–21], polycarbonates [22–24], salicylic acid [25], carboxylic acid [26–28], carbamates [29–31], ureas [32–34], ketone [35–37], oxazolidinones [38–40] and others. Among them, cyclic carbonate is an important conversion direction, which is widely used as lithium ion battery electrolyte, chemical intermediate, inert solvent, industrial lubricant, etc. So far, many paths have been studied to synthesize cyclic carbonates from CO2. Among these pathways, the cyclic esterification reaction route for the synthesis of five-membered cyclic carbonates from diols and CO2 is not only green and safe, but also allows the conversion of excess glycols (Scheme 1 ). However, in thermodynamics, it is unfavorable because of the presence of water, a by-product that accompanies the reaction of diols with CO2. To overcome the equilibrium limitation, different kinds of dehydrating agents have been used to convert diols and CO2 into cyclic carbonates, such as physical dehydrating agents like molecular sieves and chemical dehydrating agents like acetonitrile, dicyanopyridine, epoxides, etc. [41–44]. Thermodynamically, the introduction of epoxides can not only remove by-product water from cyclization reaction to break the equilibrium limit, on the other hand, the products of epoxides cycloaddition can be transesterified with EG, which further improves the yield of ethylene carbonate (EC) and can co-produce another cyclic carbonate with high added value. Therefore, based on the high value of styrene carbonate (SC), the cycloaddition product of styrene oxide (SO), SO was selected. Dynamically, different catalysts were developed [41,45,46]. Tomishige performed the first attempt of this reaction using a calcined CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst system in the presence of acetonitrile [47]. Under the optimal reaction conditions of 0.36 mmol catalyst mass (total amount of Ce and Zr), 200 mmol CO2, 120 mmol acetonitrile, 150°C and 2 h reaction, EC and PC were synthesized from EG and PG with conversions of 0.7% and 1.6%, respectively, and put forward the idea of improving the yield of cyclic carbonate by removing water from the system. Subsequently, He's research group successively reported the use of Bu2SnO / Bu2Sn(OMe)2 and Mg and its oxides in DMF solvent [41,48]. Under harsh reaction conditions (180°C, 15 MPa), the yield of PC is still less than 4%. Unfortunately, the reaction efficiency has been a bottleneck problem at present. In particular, the conventional metal-based catalysts suffer from corrosion and toxicity problems, and the addition of nitrile dehydrating agents increases the side reactions. Therefore, it is urgent to develop an efficient metal-free green catalyst and reaction strategy to realize the efficient synthesis of cyclic esterification of diols and CO2. Ionic liquid (IL) is a green medium with adjustable structure and high thermal stability [49,50]. However, ILs are rarely used in the cyclic esterification reaction of diols and CO2, and most of them are single-point ILs. As a result, the acidity and basicity of ILs would be regulated by the design of cations and anions. In the meanwhile, the catalyst can be designed to contain multiple active sites which could activate EG and CO2 at the same time, thus reducing the activation energy barrier of this reaction. In this study, a green acid-base bicentric ionic liquid systems (ABbILs) with Bronsted acid as cation and Lewis base as anion (Scheme 3) were synthesized to catalyze the cyclic esterification reaction of EG with CO2 from the dynamics point of view. Thermodynamically, the equilibrium limit is broken by adding epoxides (Scheme 2 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents CO2 is provided by Beijing Analytical Instrument Factory, and its purity is 99.99%. 1,5-Diazabicyclo[4.3.0]−5-nonene (DBN) (98%), 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec‑7-ene (DBU) (99%), 1,5,7-Triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec‑5-ene (TBD) (98%), Styrene oxide (SO) (98%), Phenol (99.5%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. Ethylene glycol (EG) (98%), Imidazole (99%), 2-Methylimidazole (98%), 2-Ethylimidazole (99%), 2-Propylimidazole (98%), Benzimidazole (98.5%), 4-Fluorophenol (99%), p-Chlorophenol (99%), 4-Bromophbenol (98%), Glutarimide (98%), Succinimide (98%), Phthalimide (98%), 1,2-Cyclohexanedicarboximide (98%) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Ethylene glycol and styrene oxide are used after dehydration, and other reagents are untreated. 2.2 Experimental instruments and methods FT-IR was recorded on a Thermo Nicolet 380 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Nicolet 380) with anhydrous KBr as the standard, and the 1H spectra were recorded in D2O, DMSO and CDCl3 on a Bruker AVANCE III HD 600 MHz spectrometer and chemical shifts were recorded relative to tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard. The ESI-MS was collected on Germany Brooke gmbh UPLC-QTOF instrument. The glass conversion temperature and decomposition temperature of ILs were measured separately on a TG-DTA 6300 thermal analyzer (NSK Ltd., Japan) in the N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°C min−1, and the test temperature range was 25–500°C. The products in liquid phase were quantificationally analyzed by Gas Chromatography (Agilent DB 8890) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a capillary column (30 m × 0.53 mm × 3.0 µm). And the qualitative analysis was further determined by GC–MS QP 2020 from Shimadzu. 2.3 Synthesis of ABbILs catalysts ABbILs was synthesized from the reported procedure [51]. Take 1,5,7-Triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec‑5-ene glutarimide ([TBDH][Glu]) as a typical Example. 10 mmol (1.3920 g) 1,5,7-Triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec‑5-ene (TBD) is dissolved in 15 mL absolute ethanol solution in 50 mL flask. 10 mmol (0.9969 g) of glutarimide is then dissolved in 15 mL absolute ethanol solution. The mixture of glutarimide was then added slowly, drop by drop, to the flask. After drip adding, stir at room temperature for 8 h. After completion of the reaction, remove the solvent by rotary evaporator at 60°C, and then transferred to a vacuum oven at 60°C for 18 h. Finally, we get the target IL [TBDH][Glu]. Other catalysts are also easily prepared by acid-base neutralization. The organic base ionic liquid was characterized by 1H NMR, FT-IR and ESI (see as in the supplementary material). 2.4 Catalytic procedure for EG and CO2 The reaction of EG and CO2 is executed in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave reactor fitted with a magnetic agitator. The standard procedure is as follows: Add EG (20 mmol,1.2400 g), SO (20 mmol, 2.4030 g) and catalyst (2 mmol) into the autoclave with a magnetic stirrer successively. After sealing, CO2 is charged into the autoclave at room temperature, stir and dissolve at 500 rpm for 15 min. After that, turn on the temperature. When the target temperature is reached, such as 100°C, open the pressure valve and slowly add CO2 pressure to the target pressure, such as 3 MPa. After the end of the reaction, the excess CO2 gas is slowly released after the autoclave is cooled to atmospheric temperature. After that, 0.2 g biphenyl was put into the autoclave reactor as internal standard for the quantitative analysis. The liquid products were quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography. And qualitative analysis was carried out by GC–MS. 2.5 Calculation method DFT calculation adopts M06–2x/Def2-TZVP//B3LYP-D3/6–311+G (d, p) level. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Analysis and characterization of ABbILs 3.1.1 The structure of ABbILs was characterized by 1H NMR [DBUH][IM]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.58 (s, 1H), 7.00 (s, 2H), 3.19 (d, J = 36.0 Hz, 6H), 2.37 (s, 2H), 1.76 (d, J = 23.4 Hz, 2H), 1.56 (d, J = 41.5 Hz, 6H). [DBUH][PhO]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.12 (d, J = 18.1 Hz, 2H), 6.81 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 6.67 (d, J = 15.5 Hz, 1H), 3.25 (d, J = 45.1 Hz, 6H), 2.48 (d, J = 9.6 Hz, 2H), 1.81 (d, J = 23.5 Hz, 2H), 1.59 (d, J = 39.3 Hz, 6H). [DBUH][Suc]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 3.55 (d, J = 36.3 Hz, 4H), 3.33 (d, J = 11.5 Hz, 2H), 2.62 (d, J = 27.3 Hz, 4H), 2.48 (d, J = 41.9 Hz, 2H), 2.02 (d, J = 23.6 Hz, 2H), 1.80 – 1.67 (m, 6H). [DBNH][Suc]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 3.69 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 2H), 3.41 (d, J = 41.5 Hz, 4H), 2.86 (d, J = 16.0 Hz, 2H), 2.65 – 2.43 (m, 4H), 2.15 (d, J = 30.6 Hz, 2H), 2.03 (d, J = 23.5 Hz, 2H). [TBDH][Suc]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 3.31 (dd, J = 44.8, 11.8 Hz, 8H), 2.53 (d, J = 94.2 Hz, 4H), 1.99 (d, J = 23.7 Hz, 4H). [TBDH][pH-Suc]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 7.55 (d, J = 68.3 Hz, 1H), 3.28 (dd, J = 45.6, 11.8 Hz, 8H), 1.96 (d, J = 23.6 Hz, 4H). [TBDH][Cy-Suc]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 3.31 (dd, J = 44.7, 11.8 Hz, 8H), 2.91 – 2.58 (m, 2H), 2.07 – 1.29 (m, 13H). [TBDH][Glu]: 1H NMR (600 MHz, D2O) δ 3.30 (dd, J = 44.8, 11.8 Hz, 9H), 2.26 (dd, J = 40.0, 15.2 Hz, 4H), 1.99 (d, J = 23.7 Hz, 4H), 1.85 (d, J = 30.4 Hz, 2H). 3.1.2 The thermogravimetric of ABbILs was characterized by TGA In addition, the thermal stability of these ABbILs was tested. Fig. 1 reveals that the ABbILs synthesized in this paper has excellent thermal stability at the reaction temperature. In ABbILs with [TBDH] as cation, the thermal decomposition temperature law of anions is as follows: [Glu]−>[Cy-Suc]−>[Suc]−>[Ph-Suc]−. For [DBUH][Suc], [DBNH][Suc], and [TBDH][Suc], which possess the same anion, the order of thermal stability of these three ionic liquids is [TBDH][Suc] > [DBNH][Suc] > [DBUH][Suc], which can be interpreted in terms of ΔpKa. As shown in Table 1 , the thermal stability of ILs is positively correlated with ΔpKa, and the larger the ΔpKa, the more stable the ionic liquid is. This conclusion is consistent with the results previously reported in the literature. [54,55] Among them, [TBDH][Glu] had the best decomposition temperature. The [TBDH][Suc] loses only 10% of its weight near 300 °C. Fig. 2 3.2 Activity evaluation of ABbILs The catalytic activities of ABbILs were investigated. Table 2 introduces the results of EC synthesis from CO2, EG and SO over different catalysts and gives the results of the conversion of EG and SO and the yields of EC, SG and SC. As shown in Entry 1–2, in the reaction system without ABbILs catalyst, no EC production was detected regardless of the presence of SO. Comparing Entry 10 & 11, only 0.5% EC yield was obtained in the absence of SO presence, while when SO was added, the EC yield reached 18.6%, which proves the promotion effect of SO on the reaction. In Entry 3, the EC yield of 35.8% was obtained by directly reacting EG with an equimolar amount of SC in the absence of catalyst, which proved that EG could react with SC to produce EC, which was consistent with the expected effect of SO. The tested Brønsted acids are iminazole, succinimide and phenol, and their pKa values in D2O of the proton donors are 6.95, 9.6, 9.89, the activity over the DBU-based ABbILs increased with the increase of pKa. Compared with the same anion, the effect of cation on the yield of EC is as follows: [TBDH]+> [DBNH]+> [DBUH]+ (Entry 5–7), which may be caused by binding energy. DFT results prove this conclusion (see as in Table 3 ). The binding energy between [TBDH][Suc] and EG is the largest, so the corresponding EC yield is the highest. Moreover, [TBDH][Suc] has the strongest hydrogen bond with EG, so the corresponding EC yield is the highest among these three ABbILs. Generally speaking, [TBDH][Glu] has the best catalytic activity among all ABbILs. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions After determining [TBDH][Glu] as the optimal catalyst, the effects of amount of catalyst, reaction temperature, CO2 pressure and reaction time on the cyclic esterification reaction were investigated. Fig. 3 (A) shows the effect of catalyst dosage on EG and SO conversions and EC and SC yields. The conversion of EG and SO increases with the amount of catalyst, the yield of EC and the total yield of cyclic carbonates showed a trend of increasing and then decreasing. The effects of temperature on the conversions of EG and SO and the yields of EC and SC are shown in Fig. 3(B). In the tested temperature range, the conversion of SO is proportional to temperature. With the increase of reaction temperature, the conversion of EG and the yield of EC were highest at 100°C, excessive temperature will lead to side reactions. The influence of CO2 pressure on the reaction system is shown in Fig. 3(C). The yield of EC increases with increasing pressure, and when the pressure exceeds 3 MPa, the yield of the target product decreases with further increase in CO2 pressure. Fig. 3(D) reveals the influence of reaction time on the target product. The highest yield of EC was achieved at 4 h. Therefore, the optimal reaction conditions were as follows: n([TBDH][Glu]):n(EG)=0.03, reaction temperature of 100°C, reaction pressure of 3 MPa, and reaction time of 4 h. Under these conditions, the yield of EC was 29.5% and the total yield of cyclic carbonates reached 52.4%. 3.4 Possible reaction mechanism In order to expound the mechanism of the reaction of ABbILs catalyst on CO2 and EG to generate EC, the interaction between reactants and [TBDH][Glu] was studied by FT-IR (Fig. 4 ). There is a new peak in FT-IR spectrum at 1701 cm−1, which belongs to the asymmetric C = O vibration of the carbamate (N−COO−) [56–58], which indicates that CO2 is activated by [TBDH][Glu]. DFT calculation results prove this conclusion. As shown in Fig. 6(B) and (E), after CO2 is combined with [TBDH]+, the C = O bond length of CO2 is extended from 1.16089 Å to 1.16505 Å. Further, we explored the interaction of the reactant EG with [TBDH][Glu] by 1H NMR to better support the reaction mechanism. Fig. 5 shows a shift in the H2 proton of EG after the interaction of EG with [TBDH][Glu], the resonance of the H2 proton of EG shifted downfield from δ 4.48 to 5.54, which demonstrated that hydrogen bond had been formed between ABbILs and EG, which had influence on the electronic density distribution of EG group. This suggested that ABbILs could activate EG as a hydrogen bond donor, and the results are consistent with some other reported catalysts. [56] DFT calculation is carried out to reveal the state that [TBDH][Glu] activates EG. As shown in Fig. 6 (A) and (D), the length of OH bond formed by hydrogen bonding between H on the cation of [TBDH][Glu] and O1 of EG is 1.88841 Å, and the length of NH bond formed by hydrogen bonding between N on anion and H1 of EG is 1.69505 Å. At the same time, we can see that the O–H bond length of the EG hydroxyl group is stretched from 0.96097 Å to 1.01014 Å after the N− of Glu− attacks EG, which demonstrated that [TBDH][Glu] possess excellent ability to active EG that may decrease the activation barrier of the reaction, leading to high reactivity. The interaction between SO and [TBDH] [Glu] was studied by 1H NMR spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 7 , the H proton located on β-C is shifted after binding with [TBDH][Glu]. This situation may be caused by the hydrogen bonding between epoxide and ionic liquid, and the hydrogen on β-C is activated, resulting in the change of the corresponding hydrogen displacement. The interaction between catalyst and SO was investigated by DFT (B3LYP) method at 6–31+G(d,P) group. In the complex of [TDBH] [Glu] and SO, the bond length of CO of SO was elongated from 1.43111 Å to 1.44927 Å, this demonstrates that the H-bonding of the H positive ion on [TBDH][Glu] promotes the ring opening of the SO. In summary, it can be considered that Lewis base site of [TBDH][Glu] activates H on the hydroxyl group of EG to form NH, Bronsted acid site activates O on the hydroxyl group of EG to form OH, and acid-base sites synergistically act to activate EG. Based on the characterization and DFT results in this work, we put forward the possible mechanism of CO2 chemical fixation reaction (Scheme 4 ). Firstly, EG is activated by hydrogen bond interaction, which may reduce the activation barrier of the reaction. Then, with the insertion of CO2, carbonate is formed. Subsequently, cyclization by intramolecular nucleophilic attack leads to cyclic carbonate accompanied by catalyst regeneration (see in Scheme 4(A)). In addition, this catalyst can also promote the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides. According to the characterization and calculation, the reaction mechanism of cycloaddition is put forward as shown in Scheme 4(B). 4 Conclusions In this paper, a series of ABbILs were designed and synthesized to catalyze the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2, EG and SO under relatively mild conditions. The ABbILs used in this route have the advantages of simple preparation process, dual active centers, high catalytic activity, green, safe and non-polluting. They have high value for industrial applications. The optimal catalyst [TBDH][Glu] screened was optimized for the reaction conditions. The optimal reaction conditions were: reaction temperature 100°C, CO2 pressure 3 MPa, reaction time 4 h, n([TBDH][Glu]) : n(EG) = 0.03. Under these conditions, the yield of EC was 29.5%, and the total yield of cyclic carbonates reached 52.4%. Through characterization and DFT calculation, the acid-base bicentered synergistic catalytic mechanism of Bronsted acid and Lewis base was proposed. This study opens up a new strategy for the cyclic esterification reaction of diols and carbon dioxide for the preparation of cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: In view of the harsh conditions of cyclic esterification reaction of ethylene glycol (EG) and carbon dioxide (CO2) to synthesize ethylene carbonate (EC), the yield is low and the catalysts are mostly metals, a series of green acid-base bicentric ionic liquids (ABbILs) were developed. Among them, the ABbILs of 1,5,7-Triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec‑5-ene glutarimide ([TBDH][Glu]) had the best catalytic performance. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the yield of EC reached 29.5%, which was higher than most of the conventional metal-based catalysts. Through activity screening results and DFT calculation, it was found that different cations affect the interaction between N on anion and H proton of EG, and the H on the cation can activate the O on EG, which would affect the ability of ABbILs to activate EG. The acid-base bicentered synergistic catalytic mechanism of Bronsted acid and Lewis base was proposed by characterization and DFT calculation. This study opens up new avenues for the efficient conversion of diols and CO2 for the preparation of cyclic carbonates.
coredata.dc:title: Acid-base bicentric ionic liquids catalytic reaction of EG and CO2 into carbonates enhanced by styrene oxide
